intro: Ulmus campestris var. angustifolia, commonly known as the narrowleaf field elm, is a variant of the field elm native to eastern North America. It is characterized by its slender, elongated leaves that are typically 3–6 inches long and have a pointed tip. The tree has a straight trunk with a broad, spreading crown and can grow up to 40 feet tall. Its bark is gray and fissured, becoming more rugged with age. This variety is often found in open woodlands and along stream banks, where it thrives in moist, well-drained soils.
